sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_1:
What is the determinant of the matrix:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 
3 & -2 & 1 \\
4 & 0 & -3 \\
-1 & 2 & 5 \\
\end{bmatrix}$$
message_2:
To find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix, we can use the following formula:

$$\det(A) = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)$$

where a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, and i are the elements of the matrix:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 
a & b & c \\
d & e & f \\
g & h & i \\
\end{bmatrix}$$

In this case, the matrix is:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 
3 & -2 & 1 \\
4 & 0 & -3 \\
-1 & 2 & 5 \\
\end{bmatrix}$$

So, a = 3, b = -2, c = 1, d = 4, e = 0, f = -3, g = -1, h = 2, and i = 5.

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

$$\det(A) = 3(0 - (-3)(2)) - (-2)(4 - (-3)(-1)) + 1(4(2) - 0)$$
$$\det(A) = 3(6) - (-2)(1) + 1(8)$$
$$\det(A) = 18 + 2 + 8$$
$$\det(A) = 28$$

So, the determinant of the matrix is 28.
